title: 115_s627
content: The Act is titled the "Maritime Washington National Heritage Area Act" and includes definitions for key terms. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms related to the Maritime Washington National Heritage Area Act, including "local coordinating entity," "management plan," "map," "National Heritage Area," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 3. Establishes the Maritime Washington National Heritage Area. The Maritime Washington National Heritage Area is established in the State, encompassing land in various counties along the shoreline as depicted on the map. The boundaries may be revised with approval from the Secretary and inclusion in the management plan. The map of the Maritime Washington National Heritage Area is available for public inspection at the National Park Service and the local coordinating entity, the Washington Trust for Historic Preservation. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The local coordinating entity must submit a proposed management plan for the National Heritage Area within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate protection, enhancement, and interpretation of resources, consider State and local plans, and include an inventory of resources in the area. The proposed management plan for the National Heritage Area should include policies, strategies, and recommendations for conservation, funding, and development. It should also outline actions by various entities to protect natural, cultural, and historical resources, along with an implementation program by the local coordinating entity. The management plan for the National Heritage Area should include actions for ongoing collaboration among partners, specific commitments for the first 5 years, identification of funding sources, and recommendations for Federal, State, and local programs. The management plan for the National Heritage Area should include coordination of Federal, State, and local programs, an interpretive plan, and policies for resource management. If the plan is not submitted within 3 years, the local coordinating entity will be ineligible. The management plan for the National Heritage Area must be approved by the Secretary within 180 days of receipt. The plan should reflect diverse interests and stakeholders in the area. Failure to submit the plan within 3 years renders the local coordinating entity ineligible for additional funding. The management plan for the National Heritage Area must be approved by the Secretary within 180 days of receipt, reflecting diverse interests and stakeholders. If disapproved, the Secretary advises the local entity of reasons and recommends revisions. The Secretary must approve the management plan for the National Heritage Area within 180 days of receiving any proposed revisions from the local coordinating entity. Any substantial amendments to the plan must also be approved by the Secretary before federal funds can be used for implementation. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary, through the local coordinating entity, may use funds for grants, agreements, staff hiring, obtaining money/services, and contracting for goods/services to implement the management plan. The local coordinating entity is responsible for preparing and submitting a management plan to the Secretary, assisting in carrying out programs and projects that protect important resource values in the National Heritage Area, and maintaining interpretive programs. The responsibilities of the local coordinating entity in the National Heritage Area include establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness of resources, identifying and restoring historic sites, ensuring clear signage, and promoting partnerships. The local coordinating entity in the National Heritage Area is responsible for promoting partnerships, considering diverse interests, conducting public meetings semiannually, and submitting annual reports on activities and finances. The local coordinating entity in the National Heritage Area must provide records for audit, ensure organizations receiving funds do the same, and promote economic viability. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In general, this Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the National Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and local coordinating entity. The Act does not modify laws authorizing Federal land management or limit the discretion of Federal land managers within the National Heritage Area. The Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws, but it does modify, alter, or amend any authorized use of Federal land under their jurisdiction. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act does not limit property owners' rights or require public access to their property. It does not change existing land use regulations or convey regulatory authority to the local coordinating entity. The local coordinating entity is authorized to reserve or appropriate water rights, but cannot alter treaty rights of Indian tribes, diminish state authority over fish and wildlife management, or create liability for private property owners regarding injuries on their property. SEC. 8. EVALUATION AND REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the National Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation will assess the progress of the local coordinating entity, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. Based on an evaluation of the National Heritage Area's accomplishments, the Secretary will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service in sustaining the area. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 authorized for this Act, with $1,000,000 limit per fiscal year. Funds remain available until expended. Federal share of costs not to exceed 50%, non-Federal share can be in-kind contributions. Secretary's assistance authority terminates 15 years after enactment.
